England failed to recognize the
Confederacy as a nation during the
Civil War, according to Dr. Charles
Francis Adams, Thursday, in the
sixth lecture of his course on
"Some Phases ot the Civil War,"
because of unforseen contingencies
and conditions without historical
parallel.
Recent investigations have upset
Dr. Adams' opinions on the cause
and effect of the Lancashire famine,
and it was on this account that he
interpolated Thursday's lecture, in
which he traced the effects which
the cotton blockade had upon the
English market. Dr. Adams found
a document last week in the Congressional Library, which was "so
new, so interesting, and so surprising," that he was forced to alter
the lectures to introduce new conclusions.
"The cotton crop of 186o," he
said, "was the largest sent to England in many years. The market
was glutted with the finished product, and the warehouses were filled
with raw material, because of a
demand for English textiles which
had sprung up all over the world.
The demand, however, quickly died
down. The social and economic
situation was unprecedented. England was stocked with a three years'
supply of cotton, and the mills were
shut down. But the South had
hoped England could not get
along without its cotton, and
thought the loss of the supply, due
to the Union blockade, was responsible for the Lancashire destitution. But that was not the case;
England, in truth, had too much
cotton.
"If the 1861 crop had reached
England, a panic would have occurred. The price of textile and
raw material would have dropped.
When, however, the blockade cut
off the supply, the manufacturers
were glad, because it gave them an
opportunity to get rid of their surplus stock. Prices rose rapidly, and
the manufacturers flourished. But
the operators in the Lancashire district were out of work. No raw
material was at hand. Over five
hundred thousand persons were at
one time dependent upon charity
on account of the shutting down
of the factories.
"Yet, in this extreme destitution,
there were no demonstrations by
these people. They did not demand
the recognition of the South, so
that they might have cotton and go

liam S. Bansemer, secretary, and
Calvin W. Chesnut. Mr. Chesnut
was a member of the first class to
study under Dean Griffin when he
came to Hopkins twenty-five years
ago.
The committee selected Thomas
C. Corner, of this city, to paint the
picture. Dean Griffin sat during
the Christmas holidays, and the
artist said that he was an exceptionally good subject, always alert
to assist him in his efforts.
It was undecided, at first, whether
the portrait should show the Dean
in street clothes or in academic
robe. After some discussion, however, the robe was selected as being
more appropriate for a University
portrait.
Mr. Corner, the artist, is being
congratulated by all who view the
painting. It is an eminently successful work, and ranks with the
"Four Doctors" as a natural picture in oil.

the men realize that their work does
not end with the long trips and the
McCoy Hall concert.
The Glee Club was better represented at Catonsville than the instrumentalists. About eighteen of
the singers were there, and the
rather small audience appreciated
their selections. Doubtless the very
cold night might be blamed for the
small turn out, both of entertainers and entertained. As Leader
Geisel of the Instrumental Club was
among those who were unable to
be present, the musicians were a
little uncertain of themselves at
times, although Melamet substituted very well, considering the
lack of practice. As a "filler," an
impromptu mandolin quartet "got
away" with a short selection. A
vocal quartet, picked from the regular octet, received the heartiest
applause. The performance was
followed by a short dance.
Two more concerts are yet to be
given—one at Clifton M. E. Church
this week, and the other at Walbrook three weeks hence.

were four sessions, one at 2.30 and
the other at 8.15 of each day, and
each one of them was presided over
by a prominent Marylander.
The Association was organized
after the last meeting of the National Conservation Congress in
Washington, at which a number of
noted citizens of this State were
present. The purpose of the society is "to further the utilization
and development, without waste,
of all the natural advantages, and
the natural resources of the State;
and to protect and preserve natural
objects of beauty and historic interest."
In accordance with these aims,
the society attempts to get legislation from the State on the subjects
of forests, game preserves, parks,
and roads. It is also favoring the
recent movement to found a State
agricultural college to be known as
the Oread School of Outdoor Life,
in which a great many well-known
Baltimoreans and countians have
become interested.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 2, 1914.

Dean Griffin.
The portrait of Dean Griffin,
recently presented to the University
by his former students, constitutes
a well-deserved tribute to the Dean
personally, and a recognition of his
twenty-five years of fruitful service to the college and the city. The
Dean did not grow up with Johns
Hopkins, as did some of his colleagues. When he came to Baltimore he had already achieved distinction as a teacher and a scholar.
A graduate of Williams College
and of Union Theological Seminary, he had spent a number of
years in the ministry and had been
a member of the faculty of Williams, where he was professor of
Latin, then professor of rhetoric,
and from 1886 to 1889, Mark Hopkins professor of intellectual and
moral philosophy. He had received
the degree of doctor of divinity.
from Amherst and that of doctor
of laws from Princeton.
Cped to Johns Hopkins in 1889
to be dean of the college faculty
and professor of philosophy, Dr.
Griffin shared the burdens and perplexities of that period of financial
distress in which the work of the
University—undergraduate as well
as graduate—had to be carried on
with very seriously diminished
revenues. How large an interest
the Dean has had in events that
have influenced the destiny of the
University may be understood
when one remembers that during
his twenty-five years of administrative service he has seen the opening of the medical department and
its speedy rise to first place among
the medical schools of the country,

the abandonment of Clifton as a
future site of the University, and
the erection of McCoy Hall, the
inauguration of President Remsen,
the gift of Homewood, the opening of the department of engineering, and the election of President
Goodnow.
In his course in logic, psychology
and ethics, officially Philosophy I,
but in fact rarely spoken of except as "the Dean's course," Dean
Griffin has taught and personally
known more than a thousand Hopkins students. It is in this course—
a fortunate survival of an earlier
day in collegiate instruction—that
the advantage of being in a relatively small college comes home
to a man. Here the seniors come
together from the specialization of
laboratories and electives to study
as one class the larger issues of
life and thought. They are as yet
few enough in number to become
well acquainted with each other,
and, what is more important, they
are able to come into personal relations with the official head of the
college. In this personal contact
with the seniors and in the impression upon them of his quiet dignity
and broad culture lies the secret
of the affection with which the collegiate alumni of a quarter of a
century regard Dean Griffin.
"Tech" Report Is of General Interest.
The report of progress on the
"Tech" buildings printed in book
form and sent by the trustees of
the University to every member of
the General Assembly of Maryland, was a comprehensive budget
of facts of really general interest.
Until the report was published,
members of the Legislature were
dependent upon the press for information, but this source, obviously,
was not wholly accurate nor ample.
Actual students in the "Tech"
department, too, have relied upon
the papers for the same information. It seems that there has not
been an extensive authoritative announcement on the part of the University to these men. They confess that they are woefully ignorant
of,Homewood plans and progress.
Why not send a copy of the
General Assembly report to each
of the "Tech" students too? The
book would be of unusual interest
to them.
The Music at the Junior Banquet.
THE NEWS-LETTER last week inadvertently printed as part of the
junior banquet story the program
of music which was in reality a
feature of the Commemoration Day
exercises. The impression was
conveyed that Edwin L. Turnbull
directed an orchestra of picked
Peabody Institute professors for
the delectation of 1915 diners.
As a matter of fact, however,
the only musical compositions heard
at the junior "feed" were "When
That Aprille," etc., to the tune of
"Good Night, Ladies," and "0
Colonia, Quae Cupis," the class
chant.

Georgetown Wins by 1 Game, but 5 of
the 534 Hopkins Victories Were
Forfeits—Bolling Gets Draw.

The chess match between teams
representing the chess clubs of
this University and of the University of Georgetown was held Thursday night at the Baltimore Chess
Club on Eutaw street.
The result was a victory for
Georgetown, by the score of six
and one-half games to five and onehalf. Each team was composed of
six men. The Hopkins representatives were Bolling, Price, Hammond (captain), Davis, Melamet
and Nachlass. The personnel of the
Georgetown team was: Whitaker
(captain), Winisatt, Knapp, Mitchell, Guerra and Whitehorn.
Although the score was a close
one, Hopkins failed to cover itself
with glory, as five of its games
were won by forfeit. Winisatt and
Whitehorn, of Georgetown, failed
to put in an - appearance, so that
Brown and Nachlass were each
credited with two games. Then,
after Whitaker had easily disposed
of Hammond in the first match, he
was called away upon an important
engagement, thus forfeiting the
second game.

Intercollegiate Conference.

Lnder the auspices of the Student Volunteer Movement, there
will be held in Levering Hall on
next Friday, Saturday and Sunday,
March 6, 7 and 8, a series of meetings for students. This missionary conference for the Colleges of
Maryland will be attended by representatives from the Various Maryland institutions all over the State,
including, in addition to Hopkins,
Goucher, St. John's, University of
Maryland, . Baltimore College of
Dental Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Hood College
(Frederick), Western Maryland,
and our Medical Department.
The conference will open Friday
evening in Levering Hall about 8
o'clock, and will be followed by a
social and "refreshment" hour, to
allow the delegates from the various colleges to become acquainted.
Three meetings will be held on Saturday at To A. M., 3 P. M., and
8 P. M. On Sunday at 5 P. M., a
meeting will be held at Goucher
College, and the closing meeting of
the conference will be held Sunday
night in Levering Hall.
The out-of-town delegates will
arrive in the city some time Friday
morning, or afternoon, and will be
entertained in the .city by students
here and at Goucher.

"TECH" PROGRESS TOLD IN BOOK

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

Trustees' Report to General Assembly
Sent in Neat Volume to Each Member—Illustrations a Feature.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

A report of progress on the new
Technical Building was made to the
General Assembly of Maryland by
the trustees . of the University in
an interesting book having for illustrations all the elevation and
plan drawings of the architects. The
buildings, it will be remembered,
were made possible through a State
appropriation of $600,000 and an
annuity of $5o,000 by the last
Legislature which met two years
ago.
A copy of the report was sent to
each member of the Assembly to
acquaint them with the state of
operation at Homewood.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building and Laboratory is reported almost finished.
It is being erected at a cost of
$285,500, which does not, however,
include the equipment for instruction. This building is under roof
at the present time, and will be
ready for occupancy next fall. The
Laboratory of Civil Engineering is
estimated to cost $150,000 without
equipment, and will cover 12,000
square feet. The equipment for
these two buildings Will cost $165,000. The total cost of these two
buildings is $600,500.
The trustees further report that
at the beginning of the term in
1913 each of the legislative districts
of Baltifnore, and with only two
exceptions, all the counties of the
State, sent representatives to the
University on free scholarships.

Elevator Complaint From "Grad."

FEBRUARY 27, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The maximum carrying capacity of the McCoy Hall
elevator is ten persons. Frequently,
after the full load number has gotten into "the old box," a few more
people also sneak in and prevent
the very courteous tender from
making ascent.
When this occurs he stands silently by his controller, refusing to
"go up." His attitude signifies
that someone has to get off and
walk. Immediately a mighty undergraduate cheer goes up. Cries of
"Who's a freshman," "Throw out
the freshman," are heard, but singularly enough, none are ever
thrown.
Now, these situations are generally solved by graduate students.
Undergraduates positively never do
get out, and finally a couple of
"grads," for the sake of harmony,
are forced to leave the elevator,
wait for another trip, or walk.
I write this simply as a suggestion to the undergraduates. I believe they will realize the mild injustice being done in preventing
the proverb: "First come, first
served," holding true in the case
of the elevator. Sincerely,
A GRAD STUDENT.

Where Lacrosse Sticks Are Made.

The only lacrosse stick factory
in the world is located at Cornwall,
Ontario, according to a consular
report from that place. The game
originated in that region, and the
Indians there have special skill in
whittling the handles of the sticks.
The factory employs ten Indians,
most of whom will work only in
Three-quarters of the
winter.
product is consumed in Canada,
the rest going to the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand,
except about one per cent, which is
sent to the United States—principally to the Carlisle Indian School
and Ithaca, N. Y.
About $2,000 worth of hickory
wood for the sticks is annually imported from the United States,
while the gut conies from England.

Night, on Friday, an illustrated
lecture by Thomas Martindale, on
his "Hunting Experiences on the

this marvelous country, as well as
a number of first-rate pictures. He
is a very keen sportsman, and noted
for his ability to tell a story.

next lecture, "The Crisis in Downing Street."
In an introduction to the lecture,
Dr. Adams said that the finding of
new material had occasioned a rearrangement both of his opinions
and lectures, and that to include
every topic would make it nece§sary to extend the course for two
more hours. If this could not be
done, he suggested dropping the
last two scheduled talks and replacing them with the new.

England failed to recognize the
Confederacy as a nation during the
Civil War, according to Dr. Charles
Francis Adams, Thursday, in the
sixth lecture of his course on
"Some Phases ot the Civil War,"
because of unforseen contingencies
and conditions without historical
parallel.
Recent investigations have upset
Dr. Adams' opinions on the cause
and effect of the Lancashire famine,
and it was on this account that he
interpolated Thursday's lecture, in
which he traced the effects which
the cotton blockade had upon the
English market. Dr. Adams found
a document last week in the Congressional Library, which was "so
new, so interesting, and so surprising," that he was forced to alter
the lectures to introduce new conclusions.
"The cotton crop of 186o," he
said, "was the largest sent to England in many years. The market
was glutted with the finished product, and the warehouses were filled
with raw material, because of a
demand for English textiles which
had sprung up all over the world.
The demand, however, quickly died
down. The social and economic
situation was unprecedented. England was stocked with a three years'
supply of cotton, and the mills were
shut down. But the South had
hoped England could not get
along without its cotton, and
thought the loss of the supply, due
to the Union blockade, was responsible for the Lancashire destitution. But that was not the case;
England, in truth, had too much
cotton.
"If the 1861 crop had reached
England, a panic would have occurred. The price of textile and
raw material would have dropped.
When, however, the blockade cut
off the supply, the manufacturers
were glad, because it gave them an
opportunity to get rid of their surplus stock. Prices rose rapidly, and
the manufacturers flourished. But
the operators in the Lancashire district were out of work. No raw
material was at hand. Over five
hundred thousand persons were at
one time dependent upon charity
on account of the shutting down
of the factories.
"Yet, in this extreme destitution,
there were no demonstrations by
these people. They did not demand
the recognition of the South, so
that they might have cotton and go

The committee selected Thomas
C. Corner, of this city, to paint the
picture. Dean Griffin sat during
the Christmas holidays, and the
artist said that he was an exceptionally good subject, always alert
to assist him in his efforts.
It was undecided, at first, whether
the portrait should show the Dean
in street clothes or in academic

more appropriate for a University
portrait.
Mr. Corner, the artist, is being
congratulated by all who view the
painting. It is an eminently successful work, and ranks with the
"Four Doctors" as a natural picture in oil.

The Association was organized
after the last meeting of the National Conservation Congress in
Washington, at which a number of
noted citizens of this State were
present. The purpose of the society is "to further the utilization
and development, without waste,
of all the natural advantages, and
the natural resources of the State;
and to protect and preserve natural
objects of beauty and historic interest."
In accordance with these aims,
the society attempts to get legislation from the State on the subjects
of forests, game preserves, parks,
and roads. It is also favoring the
recent movement to found a State
agricultural college to be known as
the Oread School of Outdoor Life,
in which a great many well-known
Baltimoreans and countians have

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 2, 1914.

Dean Griffin.
The portrait of Dean Griffin,
recently presented to the University
by his former students, constitutes
a well-deserved tribute to the Dean
personally, and a recognition of his
twenty-five years of fruitful service to the college and the city. The
Dean did not grow up with Johns
Hopkins, as did some of his colleagues. When he came to Baltimore he had already achieved distinction as a teacher and a scholar.
A graduate of Williams College
and of Union Theological Seminary, he had spent a number of
years in the ministry and had been
a member of the faculty of Williams, where he was professor of
Latin, then professor of rhetoric,
and from 1886 to 1889, Mark Hopkins professor of intellectual and
moral philosophy. He had received
the degree of doctor of divinity.
from Amherst and that of doctor
of laws from Princeton.
Cped to Johns Hopkins in 1889
to be dean of the college faculty
and professor of philosophy, Dr.
Griffin shared the burdens and perplexities of that period of financial
distress in which the work of the
University—undergraduate as well
as graduate—had to be carried on
with very seriously diminished
revenues. How large an interest
the Dean has had in events that
have influenced the destiny of the
University may be understood
when one remembers that during
his twenty-five years of administrative service he has seen the opening of the medical department and
its speedy rise to first place among
the medical schools of the country,

the abandonment of Clifton as a
future site of the University, and
the erection of McCoy Hall, the
inauguration of President Remsen,
the gift of Homewood, the opening of the department of engineering, and the election of President
Goodnow.
In his course in logic, psychology
and ethics, officially Philosophy I,
but in fact rarely spoken of except as "the Dean's course," Dean
Griffin has taught and personally
known more than a thousand Hopkins students. It is in this course—
a fortunate survival of an earlier
day in collegiate instruction—that
the advantage of being in a relatively small college comes home
to a man. Here the seniors come
together from the specialization of
laboratories and electives to study
as one class the larger issues of
life and thought. They are as yet
few enough in number to become
well acquainted with each other,
and, what is more important, they
are able to come into personal relations with the official head of the
college. In this personal contact
with the seniors and in the impression upon them of his quiet dignity
and broad culture lies the secret
of the affection with which the collegiate alumni of a quarter of a
century regard Dean Griffin.
"Tech" Report Is of General Interest.
The report of progress on the
"Tech" buildings printed in book
form and sent by the trustees of
the University to every member of
the General Assembly of Maryland, was a comprehensive budget
of facts of really general interest.
Until the report was published,
members of the Legislature were
dependent upon the press for information, but this source, obviously,
was not wholly accurate nor ample.
Actual students in the "Tech"
department, too, have relied upon
the papers for the same information. It seems that there has not
been an extensive authoritative announcement on the part of the University to these men. They confess that they are woefully ignorant
of,Homewood plans and progress.
Why not send a copy of the
General Assembly report to each
of the "Tech" students too? The
book would be of unusual interest
to them.
The Music at the Junior Banquet.
THE NEWS-LETTER last week inadvertently printed as part of the
junior banquet story the program
of music which was in reality a
feature of the Commemoration Day
exercises. The impression was
conveyed that Edwin L. Turnbull
directed an orchestra of picked
Peabody Institute professors for
the delectation of 1915 diners.
As a matter of fact, however,
the only musical compositions heard
at the junior "feed" were "When
That Aprille," etc., to the tune of
"Good Night, Ladies," and "0
Colonia, Quae Cupis," the class
chant.

Georgetown Wins by 1 Game, but 5 of
the 534 Hopkins Victories Were
Forfeits—Bolling Gets Draw.

The chess match between teams
representing the chess clubs of
this University and of the University of Georgetown was held Thursday night at the Baltimore Chess
Club on Eutaw street.
The result was a victory for
Georgetown, by the score of six
and one-half games to five and onehalf. Each team was composed of
six men. The Hopkins representatives were Bolling, Price, Hammond (captain), Davis, Melamet
and Nachlass. The personnel of the
Georgetown team was: Whitaker
(captain), Winisatt, Knapp, Mitchell, Guerra and Whitehorn.
Although the score was a close
one, Hopkins failed to cover itself
with glory, as five of its games
were won by forfeit. Winisatt and
Whitehorn, of Georgetown, failed
to put in an - appearance, so that
Brown and Nachlass were each
credited with two games. Then,
after Whitaker had easily disposed
of Hammond in the first match, he
was called away upon an important
engagement, thus forfeiting the
second game.

Intercollegiate Conference.

Lnder the auspices of the Student Volunteer Movement, there
will be held in Levering Hall on
next Friday, Saturday and Sunday,
March 6, 7 and 8, a series of meetings for students. This missionary conference for the Colleges of
Maryland will be attended by representatives from the Various Maryland institutions all over the State,
including, in addition to Hopkins,
Goucher, St. John's, University of
Maryland, . Baltimore College of
Dental Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Hood College
(Frederick), Western Maryland,
and our Medical Department.
The conference will open Friday
evening in Levering Hall about 8
o'clock, and will be followed by a
social and "refreshment" hour, to
allow the delegates from the various colleges to become acquainted.
Three meetings will be held on Saturday at To A. M., 3 P. M., and
8 P. M. On Sunday at 5 P. M., a
meeting will be held at Goucher
College, and the closing meeting of
the conference will be held Sunday
night in Levering Hall.
The out-of-town delegates will
arrive in the city some time Friday
morning, or afternoon, and will be
entertained in the .city by students
here and at Goucher.

"TECH" PROGRESS TOLD IN BOOK

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

Trustees' Report to General Assembly
Sent in Neat Volume to Each Member—Illustrations a Feature.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

A report of progress on the new
Technical Building was made to the
General Assembly of Maryland by
the trustees . of the University in
an interesting book having for illustrations all the elevation and
plan drawings of the architects. The
buildings, it will be remembered,
were made possible through a State
appropriation of $600,000 and an
annuity of $5o,000 by the last
Legislature which met two years
ago.
A copy of the report was sent to
each member of the Assembly to
acquaint them with the state of
operation at Homewood.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building and Laboratory is reported almost finished.
It is being erected at a cost of
$285,500, which does not, however,
include the equipment for instruction. This building is under roof
at the present time, and will be
ready for occupancy next fall. The
Laboratory of Civil Engineering is
estimated to cost $150,000 without
equipment, and will cover 12,000
square feet. The equipment for
these two buildings Will cost $165,000. The total cost of these two
buildings is $600,500.
The trustees further report that
at the beginning of the term in
1913 each of the legislative districts
of Baltifnore, and with only two
exceptions, all the counties of the
State, sent representatives to the
University on free scholarships.

Elevator Complaint From "Grad."

FEBRUARY 27, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The maximum carrying capacity of the McCoy Hall
elevator is ten persons. Frequently,
after the full load number has gotten into "the old box," a few more
people also sneak in and prevent
the very courteous tender from
making ascent.
When this occurs he stands silently by his controller, refusing to
"go up." His attitude signifies
that someone has to get off and
walk. Immediately a mighty undergraduate cheer goes up. Cries of
"Who's a freshman," "Throw out
the freshman," are heard, but singularly enough, none are ever
thrown.
Now, these situations are generally solved by graduate students.
Undergraduates positively never do
get out, and finally a couple of
"grads," for the sake of harmony,
are forced to leave the elevator,
wait for another trip, or walk.
I write this simply as a suggestion to the undergraduates. I believe they will realize the mild injustice being done in preventing
the proverb: "First come, first
served," holding true in the case
of the elevator. Sincerely,
A GRAD STUDENT.

Where Lacrosse Sticks Are Made.

The only lacrosse stick factory
in the world is located at Cornwall,
Ontario, according to a consular
report from that place. The game
originated in that region, and the
Indians there have special skill in
whittling the handles of the sticks.
The factory employs ten Indians,
most of whom will work only in
Three-quarters of the
winter.
product is consumed in Canada,
the rest going to the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand,
except about one per cent, which is
sent to the United States—principally to the Carlisle Indian School
and Ithaca, N. Y.
About $2,000 worth of hickory
wood for the sticks is annually imported from the United States,
while the gut conies from England.

Hunting on the Upper Yukon.

At the Hopkins Club Field
Night, on Friday, an illustrated
lecture by Thomas Martindale, on
his "Hunting Experiences on the
Upper Yukon," will be the feature.
Mr. Martindale is said to have collected some very amusing and exciting stories during his trips to
this marvelous country, as well as
a number of first-rate pictures. He
is a very keen sportsman, and noted
for his ability to tell a story.

In speaking of his next lecture,
Dr. Adams said that the crisis in
the American situation, as regarded
foreign nations, came in October,
1862, and that both Lord Parmerston and Lord Russell favored the
recognition of the South. The fate
of the Confederacy was to be settled once for all, not on the Potomac, but in Downing street, London. This will be the theme of his
next lecture, "The Crisis in Downing Street."
In an introduction to the lecture,
Dr. Adams said that the finding of
new material had occasioned a rearrangement both of his opinions
and lectures, and that to include
every topic would make it nece§sary to extend the course for two
more hours. If this could not be
done, he suggested dropping the
last two scheduled talks and replacing them with the new.
